com.reactivecascade.i

Interface IReactiveTarget<IN>

  • Type Parameters:
    IN - the type of from expected as input to this node. If this is the head of the reactive chain, it is the same type as SOURCE.
    All Superinterfaces:
    INamed
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    PersistentValue, ReactiveImageView, ReactiveInteger, ReactiveLong, ReactiveString, ReactiveValue, Subscription

    public interface IReactiveTarget<IN>
extends INamed
    An object which can receive repeated from assertions from a reactive active chain.

    Commonly used default implementations are Subscription and ReactiveValue.

    Note that classes which are functional but not reactive only receive a from one time before becoming immutable from object. These are thus _not_ IReactiveTargets because the 2nd etc firing would not be meaningful.

      • Methods inherited from interface com.reactivecascade.i.INamed

        getName

    • Method Detail

      • fire

        void fire(@NonNull
          IN in)
        An upchain IReactiveSource is notifying us of a new input from to process.

        You don't usually call the fire methods directly. They are called for you when this is an input or state change, for example by ReactiveValue.set(Object)

        Nodes within a reactive chain may choose to be stateless such as Subscription.

        Nodes at the leaf of a reactive chain will typically retain this from as state, for example (ReactiveValue).

        They may also choose to otherwise create a stateful side effect with the from received. The recommended practice is to not create such side effects except in the leaf node(s) at the end of chain branches. If you violate this rule, be warned you tend to end up with a hairy memory management and partially-completed-stateful-logic-before-exception error correction mess.

        If you would like to unlink this object when the fire operation results in an error, you must do so in an .mOnError() statement lower down in the chain you wish to trigger such an action.

        Parameters:
        in - The from from the previous link in the reactive chain.

      • fireNext

        void fireNext(@NonNull
              IN in)
        Same as fire(Object) however this is queued LIFO for more immediate execution.

        You do not generally call this directly. Chains call this for you. It is called instead of fire(Object) mid-chain to reduce work in progress and complete the task tree is an depth-first manner. This reduces the latency of individual chains once execution starts. It also decreases the peak memory load by more rapidly flushing intermediate values to the leaf node side effects of the chain.

        Parameters:
        in - The from from the previous link in the reactive chain.

      • subscribeSource

        void subscribeSource(@NonNull
                     String reason,
                     @NonNull
                     IReactiveSource<IN> reactiveSource)
        Notification that an IReactiveSource will start sending updates

        This allows the target which is responsible for holding a strong reference to the source to prevent it from being garbage collected until all targets of a given source go out of scope and are themselves garbage collected.

        You may manually speed this process by calling unsubscribeSource(String, IReactiveSource), however if you choose not to or forget to do so, it will be taken care of for you fairly soon.

        Parameters:
        reactiveSource -

      • unsubscribeSource

        void unsubscribeSource(@NonNull
                       String reason,
                       @NonNull
                       IReactiveSource<IN> reactiveSource)
        Notification that an IReactiveSource will no longer send updates

        Since this target is responsible for holding a reference to the source to keep it from being garbage collected, this target can not forget the source and, if not used elsewhere, it can be garbage collected.

        Parameters:
        reason -
        reactiveSource -

      • unsubscribeAllSources

        void unsubscribeAllSources(@NonNull
                           String reason)
        Remove all up-chain branches from this node of the reactive function tree
